16-year-old Luke O’Donnell makes his debut for Derry City First Team

16-year-old Luke O’Donnell made his senior debut on Friday evening.

O’Donnell became the fourth academy product to make his competitive debut for the first team during the 2023 season.

Luke joins a distinguished list of Inishowen talents who have proudly worn the Candy-Striped jersey.

16-year-old Luke O’Donnell makes his debut for Derry City First Team

47-goal graduate signs first professional contract with Liverpool FC

Trent Kone-Doherty signs first professional contract with Liverpool FC.

The pacey winger scored 47 goals in three and a half years at the Derry Academy.

The 17-year-old also scored on his Under-21 debut for Liverpool this season.

Trent Kone-Doherty, a product of the Derry City Academy, has signed his first professional contract with Liverpool Football Club. Trent made the move to Liverpool in July 2022 after impressing during his time in the youth ranks at Brandywell.

Continue reading “47-goal graduate signs first professional contract with Liverpool FC” →

51 years ago this week, Derry City withdrew its membership from the Irish League

• On Saturday, October 7, 1972, Derry City played their final game in the Irish League.

• On Monday, October 9, 1972, the Irish League Management Committee met to vote on a proposal put forward by Portadown Football Club, that Derry should be allowed to return to play their home games at Brandywell.

• On Friday, October 13, 1972, The Derry City board withdrew their membership of the Irish League.

51 years ago this week, a significant chapter in the history of Derry City Football Club unfolded.

Continue reading “51 years ago this week, Derry City withdrew its membership from the Irish League” →

Boyce reaches 100 appearances for Derry City

Historic night in the Savon Sanomat Areena as Derry City draw 3-3 with Kuopion Palloseura (KuPS).

Academy graduate makes his 100th appearance for the club.

Derry secures a place in the third qualifying round of a European competition for only the second time in the club’s history.

It was a historic night in the Savon Sanomat Areena on Thursday when Derry City drew 3-3 with Kuopion Palloseura (KuPS) to reach the third qualifying round of the UEFA Conference League. Michael Duffy’s sublime headed equaliser on 69 minutes proved decisive as the Candy Stripes went through, 5-4 on aggregate.

For only the second time in the club’s history, Derry sealed their place in the third qualifying round of a European competition.

But for one player, there was another reason to celebrate.

City defender Ronan Boyce reached a personal milestone by making his 100th appearance in a Derry jersey. He played the full ninety minutes and delivered a solid performance that we are so used to seeing in the full-back role.

“He is an outstanding young player with the right mentality and someone who can help drive this club forward and it wouldn’t surprise me in years to come if he became captain of this club.” – Ruaidhri Higgins.

Ronan is a graduate of the Derry City Academy and is one of its greatest success stories.

Six years ago, in July 2017, he made his academy debut as a 16-year-old and quickly became an integral part of Gary Duffy’s Under-17 side. He made a substitute appearance as City defeated Dundalk 5-2 in the Mark Farren Memorial Cup and has gone from strength to strength ever since.

The defender, who joined the Brandywell side from his local club Swilly Rovers, made his senior competitive debut as a second-half substitute against Cork City in 2019. He scored his first senior goal in a 1-1 draw against Drogheda United in April 2021.

Ronan is the perfect role model for any academy prospects who are looking to pursue a full-time career in the game. His seamless transition from the youth set-up to a regular starter in the first team has been inspiring and shows what can be achieved with the proper attitude and application.

“It’s great that Ronan has been given his first professional contract. He fully deserves this and it’s good for the club and the Academy as it shows what can be achieved.”

“He’s a very good defender who is comfortable on the ball and he has a great attitude. Hopefully, he goes on to make many first-team appearances and has a long and successful career.” – Under-19 coach, Shaun Holmes.

Ronan was rewarded for his fine form with a call-up to the Republic of Ireland U21 squad for the UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualifiers against Bosnia & Herzegovina and Luxembourg in August 2021.

He made 36 appearances and scored 7 goals in his first year as a senior professional. The Ramelton native was voted the Players’ Player of the Year in 2021.

Still only 22 years old, Ronan is one of nine players in the current first-team squad to have progressed through the club’s youth set-up.

We would like to congratulate Ronan on his 100th appearance and look forward to seeing him make many more for the Club.

Injured star ruled out of Super Cup NI

Injured star ruled out of Super Cup NI

Derry City prospect Mikey Harkin will miss the Super Cup NI tournament due to injury.

It is the worst possible feeling for the Dungiven native who was due to represent County Derry in the prestigious competition, which kicks off tomorrow (Monday 24), but he picked up an injury during a school game six weeks ago. He was hoping to recover in time, but unfortunately, it wasn’t to be.

Mikey, who has represented Northern Ireland at U16 level, is gutted to miss the tournament after putting his heart and soul into being ready.

He played his formative years with Dungiven Celtic and has been a prolific goal scorer at the Derry Academy since his debut in March 2022.

He is now working hard to get back to full fitness and will continue his rehabilitation with the Derry physio team this week and hopes to be back in action by the end of August.

We wish Mikey all the best in his recovery and look forward to seeing him back in action soon.

McGinty scores first senior goal on his competitive debut

At just 17 years and 151 days, Tiernan McGinty marks dream debut with a goal.

It was a memorable evening for one Donegal native at the Ryan McBride Brandywell Stadium on Friday evening.

Tiernan McGinty, who is from Falcarragh, came off the bench to score his first senior goal on his competitive debut for Derry City.

The talented midfielder converted from close range after some superb work by Ben Doherty to seal a fine 2-0 win over Cork City in the Airtricity League Premier Division.

Commenting on his debut, City Manager Ruairdhrí Higgins had the following to say.

“Amazing, 17 years of age, he was exceptional in training on Monday. That’s the reason why we put him on, he trained extremely well.

“He’s got that capability of getting into the box and with that athleticism he can get goals from midfield.

“I’m delighted for him.”

McGinty has produced a number of consistent performances in his time at the Derry City Academy and fully deserves the opportunity to showcase his talent on the national stage.

At just 17 years and 151 days, Tiernan still has time on his side to become a permanent feature in the first team, while a loan deal could also be a possibility to help further his development.

He becomes the second player from the academy to make his first-team debut this year, following in the footsteps of Drumkeen native Sean Patton, who made his bow against UCD last month.

Since 2019, the Candy Stripes have handed ten products from the youth setup a senior debut, with six players coming from Donegal.

A tireless worker with a strong mentality and an eye for goal, McGinty has been an ever-present in the academy squads since making his debut in the EA Sports U17 League fixture against Dundalk at Oriel Park in March 2022.

McGinty signed his first professional contract with the club in August 2022.

Tiernan played his junior football with Glenea United.

Sean Patton and Tiernan McGinty sign first professional contracts

16-years-olds, Sean Patton and Tiernan McGinty sign pro forms for Derry City.

The lads will start full time training with the first team squad in January allowing them to focus their full attention on their development.

Derry City Manager, Ruaidhri Higgins: “These are two players- amongst others- that we have identified as having the potential to be part of our first team set-up in the coming years.”

16-years-olds, Sean Patton and Tiernan McGinty have penned their first professional contracts with Derry City less than six months after making their debuts for the club’s U17 side.

Darragh named in Northern Ireland U19 panel for Football Federations Cup

Derry City’s Darragh McCloskey has received a call-up to the Northern Ireland U19 squad for the Football Federations Cup in Albir.

Darragh – who is part of the JD Irish FA Academy and National Performance Programme – features heavily for the Derry City U17s.

The promising centre-back has made great strides in his development over the past 12 months and has been rewarded for his impressive performances with Northern Ireland U17s in the Euro qualifiers back in the autumn.

Former City academy defender, Bobby Deane has also been included in the panel.

We would like to wish Darragh all the best in the tournament which begins next week.

Continue reading “Darragh named in Northern Ireland U19 panel for Football Federations Cup” →

Ronan Boyce scored his first senior goal for the Candy Stripes in their one-all draw with Drogheda United on Friday evening.

The 19-year-old, who is a product of the club’s youth setup, took advantage of some slack Drogheda defending to powerfully head home Will Patching’s pinpoint cross, five minutes before the break.

Underage results week-ending May 19

It was a mixed weekend for City’s underage sides with two wins and two defeats from the four games played.

SSE Airtricity Under-15 Group One:

Derry City 0-1 Sligo Rovers

Birdell Bosakani (Sligo)

On Saturday afternoon, Conor Loughrey’s U15 outfit hosted Sligo Rovers at the Ryan McBride Brandywell Stadium looking for a win that would propel them to the top of Group One. Derry came into the fixture on the back of three straight victories over Mayo FC, Finn Harps and Longford Town, scoring twelve times in the process and without conceding.

Continue reading “Underage results week-ending May 19” →
